title: HTML Text Formatting
description: HTML provides several elements for defining text with special meaning and style emphasis.
sub1_desc: Formatting elements are used to style text in different ways â€” to show importance, highlight changes, or indicate meaning.
example1:
This text is bold

This text is important!
note1: Note: The <b> tag makes text bold without extra importance, while <strong> indicates important text.
sub2_desc: The <i> tag defines text in an alternate mood or voice (e.g., a technical term or a foreign phrase), while <em> emphasizes meaning and is recognized by screen readers.
example2:
This text is italic

This text is emphasized
tip1: Tip: Use <em> for semantic emphasis and <i> for stylistic changes.
sub3_desc: Use <mark> to highlight important or relevant words, and <small> to show less prominent information or side notes.
example3:
Don't forget to buy milk today!

This is smaller text.
note2: Note: Marked text is often shown with a yellow background to attract attention.
sub4_desc: The <del> tag shows deleted text (strikethrough), while <ins> marks inserted or newly added text (usually underlined).
tip2: Tip: Place <del> and <ins> on separate lines or with spacing to avoid overlapping styles.
sub5_desc: <sub> displays text below the baseline (commonly used for chemical formulas), while <sup> raises text above the baseline (used for footnotes or exponents).
tip3: Tip: These tags are great for scientific and mathematical notations.
sub6_desc: The <sup> tag defines superscript text, often used for exponents or footnotes.
note3: Note: Superscript text appears slightly above the normal text line.
summary:
• Use <b> or <strong> for bold text.
  • Use <i> or <em> for italic/emphasized text.
  • Use <mark> for highlighted text.
  • Use <small> for smaller, secondary text.
  • Use <del> and <ins> to show removed or added content.
  • Use <sub> and <sup> for subscript and superscript text.
